page.title: 18POLWARTH KIRK 1
page.content: POLWARTH KIRK IS SAID TO BE OF ANCIENT ORIGIN, POSSIBLY DATING FROM 900 AD BUT IT WAS RESTORED IN THE DUTCH MANNER IN THE LATE 17 CENTURY AS A THANKSGIVING BY SIR PATRICK HUME ON HIS SAFE RETURN FROM EXILE IN HOLLAND. IT CONTAINS HIS SUCCESSOR'S COFFIN & THAT OF SEVERAL KINSMEN IN THE OPEN VAULT WHICH CAN BE SEEN THROUGH A GRILLE AT THE EAST END OF THE CHURCH WHICH HAS A CROWNED ORANGE AT ITS APEX. THIS WAS SIR PATRICK HUME'S CREST WHICH HE FREQUENTLY HAD STAMPED IN GOLD ON THE LEATHER BINDING OF HIS BOOKS & THAT HE HAD BEEN ALLOWED BY A GRATEFUL SOVREIGN, HAVING BEEN INSTRUMENTAL IN THE ACCESSION OF WILLIAM OF ORANGE. ORIGINALLY THE MANSE, WHICH WAS BUILT BY LORD MARCHMONT WHEN HE BUILT HIS OWN HOUSE, WAS LIVED IN BY THE MINISTER.
